newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Star Wars success boost News Corp profits.
newsitem.headline: Star Wars success boost News Corp profits.

text.p: Rupert Murdoch's global media conglomerate News Corp Ltd posted a sharp rise in third-quarter profits on Thursday, the force of its profits driven by the re-release of the Star Wars movie trilogy.

News Corp, based in Australia but also listed in London and New York, said net profit before abnormal items for the three months to March 31 had risen to A$376 million (US$293 million) from A$281 million, a rise of around 34 percent.
Net profits after abnormals were A$330 million, up from A$77 million in the same period last year.
Largely responsible for the rise were News Corp's Fox Television and Fox Films and its successful re-release of the updated Star Wars trilogy.
"Since being released at the end of January Star Wars has generated US$138 million at the domestic box office, with the two sequels adding another US$111 million to date," News said.
Operating income from its Filmed Entertainment division, which includes Fox Films, rose to A$82 million from A$63 million in the same period a year earlier, News said.
Filmed Entertainment revenues rose to A$1.138 billion from A$584 million.
News said its British newspapers and satellite television unit BSkyB also made significant contributions to profits.
The main drags on profits came from News' book publishing arm HarperCollins and Australasian newspaper and pay television, the group said.

There was an abnormal loss of A$46 million for the quarter, compared with a A$204 million loss in the previous comparable quarter. The loss related in part to the end of the CD-ROM publishing divisions at HarperCollins and News International.
"These results reflect strong double digit earnings increases at all of the company's core operating segments with the exception of Book Publishing," News said.
"HarperCollins' results were off against last year reflecting weaker U.S. industry trends."

Murdoch last year predicted that News could achieve a 20-percent profit rise for the year, a forecast that was not borne out by first-half results. Thursday's figures put the group back on track to achieve that rise.
